newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo stocks end up as yen fall spurs blue chips.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo stocks end up as yen fall spurs blue chips.

text.p: Tokyo stocks closed moderately higher on Friday, as the yen's decline against the dollar invited buying in blue-chip exporters, brokers said.
The 225-share Nikkei average gained 103.41 points, or 0.54 percent, to end at 19,326.03. It briefly climbed as high as 19,466.35. Its September futures were up 160 points at 19,440.

"This much of a decline in the yen will not affect exporters fundamentally, but what is important is the trend backs up investors psychologically," said Mikio Takada, general manager at Nikko Securities Co Ltd.
Towa's trading volume, at 8.266 million, was the third heaviest.
Towa's shares were hit by rumours that it is experiencing business difficulties. Officials at the firm were not available to comment on the rumours, due to a company holiday.

Shares in Fujita Corp, Towa's parent, hit a record low of 79 yen. They ended down 15 yen or 14.29 percent at 90 yen as the third-largest percentage loser. Fujita was the most actively traded issue, with a turnover of 13.79 million.
By sector, gainers were led by rubber, warehousing, pulp/paper, and miscellaneous manufacturing.
The major losers were iron/steel, shipbuilding, gas, and construction.
The second section index ended 10.84 points higher at 1,680.12, with 6.61 million shares traded. The over-the-counter (OTC) index was down 7.39 points at 1,064.85.
